column1: This table contains data about frozen scheduled flights. This information is shown in the program "Line Maintenance Manager".

column5: Description
Information about the location / stand of the aircraft after arrival.
A position where the aircraft is parked between landing and next takeoff.
Information about the location / stand of the aircraft before departure.
Suffix which is appended to the usual flight number when it is delayed in order to help on distinction with regular flights.
AMOS-wide unique identifier for a leg
Aircraft registration of the scheduled flight
Operator part of the flight number of the scheduled flight.
Number part of the flight number of the scheduled flight.
Standard code, which identifies the purpose of the leg, e.g. J = Service Normal; C = Charter; P = Ferry; T = Technical Test; K = Training
Scheduled departure date of the scheduled flight
Scheduled departure time of the scheduled flight, in minutes
Estimated departure date of the scheduled flight. Fill in, if you know that there is a delay. The A/C Browser can use this information.
Estimated departure time of the scheduled flight, in minutes. Fill in, if you know that there is a delay. The A/C Browser can use this information.
Scheduled departure airport of the scheduled flight
Scheduled arrival date of the scheduled flight
Scheduled arrival time of the scheduled flight
Estimated arrival date of the scheduled flight. Fill in, if you know that there is a delay. The A/C Browser can use this information.
Estimated arrival time of the scheduled flight. Fill in, if you know that there is a delay. The A/C Browser can use this information.
Scheduled arrival airport of the scheduled flight

The estimated leg duration for this leg, calculated in minutes. Note, that this value can be taken into account for matters of forecast calculation. The suggested strategy for this value is like this: If one knows roughly about the usual raw flight time (i.e. the difference in minutes between the value of landing date time and the value of airborne date time) of this scheduled leg, then this particular value is used. Otherwise, the difference in minutes between the value "sched_arrival_date_time" and "sched_departure_date_time" is used.
Number of cycles for the scheduled flight (touchdowns)
Calculated total aircraft hours after touchdown of the scheduled flight, in minutes
Calculated total aircraft cycles after touchdown of the scheduled flight

column1: This table contains data about changes in Total Aircraft Hours (TAH) resp. Total Aircraft Cycles (TAC), which occurred for arrived legs.

column5: Description
AMOS-wide unique identifier for a change in TAH or TAC, which occurred for an arrived leg.
AMOS-wide unique identifier for a leg.

This column can be used to sort the entries, in case that for one certain leg, several changes in TAH or TAC have occurred for that particular leg. The higher this sort ID is, the newer is the change in TAH or TAC.
Defines, what was the originator for the change in TAH or TAC: 1 = Netline import of data 2 = Manual change in module "Aircraft Utilization"

In case that the Netline import of data was the originator for the change in TAH or TAC (see column "source_of_change"), then this column specifies the column "recno" in the table "ac_util_netl_two_hist" (in addition to the matching "legno_i"), where the originating data set can be found.
This column should only be used by the dedicated workflow, which is a separate process and can notify users of a change in TAH or TAC. When notification is done, this column is set to "Y".
The TAH (measured in minutes) of the leg, before the change in TAH or TAC happened.

The delta (measured in minutes) of the new TAH of the leg, compared to the old TAH. Note: This value can also be zero, if only the TAC of this leg has changed. E.g.: Old TAH: 5000:00 hours, New TAH: 5001:25 hours, so delta is: + 85 minutes.
The TAC of the leg, before the change in TAH or TAC happened.

The delta of the new TAC of the leg, compared to the old TAC. Note: This value can also be zero, if only the TAH of this leg has changed. E.g.: Old TAC: 3000 cycles, New TAC: 2998 cycles, so delta is: - 2 cycles.
The mutation date of this record as AMOS date.
The AMOS user who changed this record.
The status of the record. This column has a different meaning for every table.
The time when this record has been added or changed in milliseconds since the start of the day.
The AMOS user who created this record.
The creation date of this record as AMOS date.

Airborne date of the leg. This value is taken to calculate the length of the leg, which is then after the landing added to the total aircraft hours performed by this aircraft.
Airborne time of the leg, in minutes. This value is taken to calculate the length of the leg, which is then after the landing added to the total aircraft hours performed by this aircraft.

A Netline-specific code, which describes the current state of the leg. Possible values are e.g. SKD = planned leg; CNL = cancelled leg; OUT = off-block; DEP = airborne; ON = landed; ARR = arrived on-block
IATA delay code, e.g. 41 = AIRCRAFT DEFECTS

column1: This table contains data about arrived legs. You find information about the history of the legs for the aircraft. Based on this, calculations can be performed.

column5: Description
External key to uniquely identify this leg in the data delivering legacy system.
Suffix which is appended to the usual flight number when it is delayed in order to help on distinction with regular flights.
AMOS-wide unique identifier for a leg
Aircraft registration of the leg
Real arrival date of the leg. This value is meant to be the landing / touchdown date of the leg (and not the on-block date of the leg)

Continuous number to be able to sort the legs by aircraft and arrival_date. The value 0 means, that this leg is a so called "null leg" (the aircraft actually didn`t fly on that day). The value 1 means the first leg of that aircraft on that day, the value 2 the second leg of that aircraft on that day, etc.

If the column "recno" has the value 0, then this column "null_leg_commited" describes, whether the "null leg" of the aircraft on that day is confirmed (then the TAH and TAC values of the aircraft can be updated) or is unconfirmed (i.e. there is still the possibility that leg data for that aircraft and day exists, but it`s not in the AMOS system yet and therefore, the TAH and TAC values of the aircraft can NOT be updated).

Flight number of the leg (carrier + number). The optional flight suffix is not part of the leg_number column and is always in the dedicated fn_suffix column. Please be aware that the fn_carrier and fn_number columns are only filled by interface and not for flights entered in APN 206 or APN 1573.
Operator part of the flight number of the leg. Please be aware that this column is only filled by interface and not for flights entered in APN 206 or APN 1573.
Number part of the flight number of the leg. Please be aware that this column is only filled by interface and not for flights entered in APN 206 or APN 1573.
Standard code, which identifies the purpose of the leg, e.g. J = Service Normal; C = Charter; P = Ferry; T = Technical Test; K = Training

Note: this database column is solely used by the AMOS "Simulator" modules (Flight Training companies). This means that for "normal" AMOS Customers operating or managing Aircraft / Helicopters, this DB column is not being filled anymore, effective with AMOS Stable V11.00. If you use a Netline System to import flight data: look in DB Table "ac_util_netl_detail", column "netline_leg_id" in case you want to retrieve the corresponding Netline-internal ID of a flight by matching the AMOS flight`s unique DB key "ac_utilization.legno_i" with "ac_util_netl_detail.legno_i". If you use some other FlightOPS system (e.g. AIMS, PDC.dk): look in DB Table "leg_additional", column "ext_system_leg_id" in case you want to retrieve the corresponding OPS System-internal ID of a flight (if that ID is provided at all, might be NULL if not supported by OPS System) by matching the AMOS flight`s unique DB key "ac_utilization.legno_i" with "leg_additional.legno_i".
Departure date of the leg. This value is meant to be the airborne date of the leg (and not the off-block date of the leg)
Departure time of the leg, in minutes. This value is meant to be the airborne time of the leg (and not the off-block time of the leg)
The real departure airport of the leg
Scheduled departure date of the leg
Scheduled departure time of the leg, in minutes
Scheduled departure airport of the leg

Arrival time of the leg, in minutes. This value is meant to be the landing / touchdown time of the leg (and not the on-block time of the leg). Note: to work with the arrival date of the leg, use the column "validity" in this table.
The real arrival airport of the leg
Scheduled arrival date of the leg
Scheduled arrival time of the leg, in minutes
Scheduled arrival airport of the leg
Duration of the leg, in minutes
Number of cycles for the leg (touchdowns)
Total aircraft hours for the aircraft after touchdown of the leg, in minutes
Total aircraft cycles for the aircraft after touchdown of the leg
Similar to the column "service_type", but contains an additional AMOS internal standard code, which identifies the purpose of the leg, e.g. NL = null leg

position of a topic regarding the document within a task

The corresponding configuration number (attribute @CONFNBR), might be null. From the spec: "Identifies a unique configuration of a pageblock. (Note that this is NOT the same as the AMTOSS/JEMTOSS Configuration Letter.)"
The sheet number for a sheet within a graphic. Unique per graphic element, but not necessarily unique in the document itself.
Unique identifier

Page block number, might be null.

The corresponding sequence number, might be null.

From the spec:  "Identifies when the accomplishment of a task/subtask requires different procedures or maintenance resources. The first character of a three character element of the sixth position of a task or a subtask (xx-xx-xx-xxx-xxx- Xxx-xxx). This is based on the AMTOSS/JEMTOSS numbering scheme."
The last two digits of a three-character element at the sixth position of a task or subtask number (xx-xx-xxxxx-xxx-xXX-xxx). Identifies variants of a particular sequence number of a task or subtask.
Unique key for this entry, might be null.

Is the stored information related to single persons? If yes, the information is protected by a special license in "Statistic Analyzer"

Is the value cumulated or explicit set? Statistic entries like "Amount of logins" might be incremented each time a user logs into the system while "Amount of online users" might be recorded every hour based on the actual figures without any relation to the previously stored entry. Is used in case of an server shutdown to prefill the hashed counters for cumulative entries

Type of interruption / consequence, which is coming from the OPS System: ARR = Delay CNL = Cancellation Note, that most of the time, this type is the same than the one in the field leg_state. Only if the OPS System delivers a newer state of the delay / cancellation, then this value might change.

This value signals in case of a cancellation, whether the cancelled flight has been accomplished subsequently by another aircraft. The field reflects the value, which is coming from the OPS System. Initially, this value is the same like the value of the field "canc_flight_tech_leasing".

Delay Code, see "Basic Data Admin, Basic Table Delay Code". For example 41 = AIRCRAFT DEFECTS (IATA). This field reflects the first delay code, which this delay / cancellation has in the OPS System. Deprecated: use table delay_cnl_import_detail.

Only for taskcards: main A/C zone concerned. Comes from msc_zone_type.zone
Only for taskcards: check package sequence code. Comes from msc_taskcard_version.cp_sequence_no
Only for taskcards: main type code. Comes from msc_type_code.typecode

Classifies the event type. One of the following values are allowed: C: for Checks D: for Documents, W: for Workorders, T: for Block Taskcards, Q: for Single Running and On Demand Taskcards P: for Part Requirements, V: for Part Replacements, JC: for Jobcards, CU: for Customer Requirements For types C, D, T Q and P, there are also corresponding CR, DR, TR, QR and PR types which are used for future events of those types.
The unique key of the event itself. Information in this column is redundant. Rotables: reqseqno_i Checks: checkno_i Documents: docno_i Taskcard: taskcard_verno_i Workorder: not used

Contains the workorder number, only applicable in case it is a workorder
Filled with the internal id of the rotable. Only valid for Rotable events,Component workorders and Rotable documents.
Indicates the psn which has to be removed which can be different from the psn of the Document Maintenance Requirement or Rotable Maintenance Requirement
The unique event_perfno_i of the removal event linked to this forecast entry.
Contains the very important data to classify the event. Used as display in program Maintenance forecast.
`s` stands for scheduled and `u` for unscheduled events. All events are per default unscheduled. Only workorder events can be unscheduled.
The estimated man hours in minutes to perform the event.
Estimated Manhours of the linked Maintenance Requirements. It is especially used for the Manhours of the Taskcards linked to a Check
The estimated ground time in minutes to perform the event.

- empty if no qulification for this event - `?` if 1..n qualifications, but all without short code - `*` at the beginning, if some qualifications have short code, but others not - `*` at the end, if more than 10 qualifications with short code
Only valid for workorder events.
Priority of wo transfer.
`Y` if feedback is required, otherwise `N`

Each position of the string represents a special characteristic of the event @see AbstractEvent.getSpecialFlagFor(): 0 = ">" 1 = Deprecated: no longer filled! - Pickslip status  2 = HIL (wo_header) 3 = MEL (wo_header_more & wo_header_crx) 4 = ORIGIN (W=wo/R=rotable/C=check/D=document) 5 = REPETITIVE (O=one time/R=repetitive) 6 = WORKORDER PRINTED (PRINTED_BY) (Y=yes/N=no) 7 = W/O issued for removed rotable (Y=yes/N=no) / rotable link OK 8 = W/O for an event (R/C/D) still open (O=open/C=closed) 9 = W/O cannibalized (Y/-) 10 = AOG-Risk (Y/" ") 11 = Taskcard-W/O ? (T/" ") 12 = Within tolerance ("Y"/"N") 13 = Tree-Rotable ? (Y/"-") 14 = Hangar_Required (Y/"-") 15 = Exists check package (Y/-)      16 = Component on open internal or external order (order type R,W,X,C) 17 = Has the event links `Y`,`N` 18 = Has the event remarks `Y`,`N` 19 = Interpolarized toGo value `Y`,`N` 20 = Mandatory event `Y`, `N` 21 = WO approval state (short code from APPROVAL_STATE) 22 = Deprecated: no longer filled! - Taskcard Man Hours for panel available (only valid for single running taskcards). 23 = In case the event was extended `Y` else `N` 24 = Document Event Sate `N`=removal not required, `B`=removal req. without order state ,`U`=removal req. with order state unknown (od_order_doc.performed=U)(documents only) 25 = Entry in wo_stages exists then `Y`, else `N` ONLY FOR WO 26 = Failure case for workorder exists then `Y` else `N` ONLY FOR WO 27 = Repeated item for workorder exists then `Y` else `N` ONLY FOR WO 28 = In case an entry in wo_reference exist `Y`, else `N` ONLY FOR WO 29 = In case an entry in msc_task_req_extension exists `Y` else `N` ONLY FOR SINGLE RUNNING TC 30 = Event classification `L`(Line maintenance), `H`(Heavy maintenance), `` unspecified valid for all events except the workorders. 31 = Marker if for the workorder/SRT a techquery has been raised and the status of this query `-`:no query. `C`: closed, `O` open, `I`: Interrupted 32 = Marker whether the workorder is for a component or an aircraft 33 = Run Required ? (Y/"-") 34 = Skill-Level as it may be defined on the wo shops (feature for GOL)  (0 - 9) 35 = Is the workorder ready for being closed? (Y/"-") (required for the ACJC process) 36 = The type of the workorder (wo_header.type) 59 = "<" (end marker of the special flags)

column1: This table contains data, which a label can possess additionally to the "normal" data, which is contained in the table "history".

column5: Description
A unique identifier for additional data on a label. See AMOS System Parameter 773 (LAST INDEX LABEL_ADDITIONAL).
The label number, for which this additional data set is necessary.
Contains the locid for which the Label was booked in the System (locid = Position according to "Aircraft Configuration Management")
Human-readable abbreviation code for the numeric ID of field "locid_pk", e.g. LH

Contains the numeric "Functional Position ID" database value for which the Label was booked in the System (used only in "Component Tree Label Booking", since AMOS Stable V12.00 due to new "Configuration Management"). See also DB Table "conf_fp".
Contains the human-readable abbreviation code for the numeric ID of the field "tree_func_pos_locid_pk" in this DB Table here, e.g. "POS_1".

When a Removal is booked during a Label Booking transaction, then this column will contain the "locationno_i" ID of the "U/S (Unserviceable) Location" at which the removed Rotable is located after Removal. The value of this ID represents the Station, Store and Location, and these values are entered by the user during a Label Booking transaction. See also columns "history.station", "label_additional.removal_store" and "label_additional.removal_us_location" to find the respective properties which this "locationno_i" ID had at the time of the Label Booking.

When a Removal is booked during a Label Booking transaction, then this column will contain the Store at which the removed Rotable is located after Removal. The value itself is entered by the user during a Label Booking transaction. See also column "label_additional.removal_us_locationno_i".

When a Removal is booked during a Label Booking transaction, then this column will contain the U/S (Unserviceable) Location at which the removed Rotable is located after Removal. The value itself is entered by the user during a Label Booking transaction. See also column "label_additional.removal_us_locationno_i".

When a Label Booking transaction is performed (be it "Rotables Label Booking" or "Component Tree Label Booking"), then this column contains the "PSN" value (= Internal AMOS Database ID of a Rotable) of the "Highest Assy" Rotable (e.g. an Engine), as soon as that "Highest Assy" Rotable is different from the Removal- resp. Installation-Rotables used during the Label Booking. I.e. the column`s value is NULL, when the Label Booking is done for Rotables positioned directly on "Aircraft Level". The column is however different from NULL, when the Label Booking is either done for LRU-Parts located within Higher Assemblies in an Aircraft, or for a "Component Tree Label Booking" (= Assembly in a Shop). Note that this column is about the "Highest Assy". To get info about the "Higher Assy" of a Label Booking, one can still find this data in the "history" DB table.

When a Label Booking transaction is performed (be it "Rotables Label Booking" or "Component Tree Label Booking"), then this column contains the "Partnumber" value of the "Highest Assy" Rotable (e.g. an Engine), as soon as that "Highest Assy" Rotable is different from the Removal- resp. Installation-Rotables used during the Label Booking. I.e. the column`s value is NULL, when the Label Booking is done for Rotables positioned directly on "Aircraft Level". The column is however different from NULL, when the Label Booking is either done for LRU-Parts located within Higher Assemblies in an Aircraft, or for a "Component Tree Label Booking" (= Assembly in a Shop). Note that this column is about the "Highest Assy". To get info about the "Higher Assy" of a Label Booking, one can still find this data in the "history" DB table. Note also that the "Partnumber" value of the "Highest Assy" Rotable is the value which it had at the time of the Label Booking; the current "Partnumber" for the respective Rotable could have changed in the meantime for instance due to Modification.

When a Label Booking transaction is performed (be it "Rotables Label Booking" or "Component Tree Label Booking"), then this column contains the "Serialnumber" value of the "Highest Assy" Rotable (e.g. an Engine), as soon as that "Highest Assy" Rotable is different from the Removal- resp. Installation-Rotables used during the Label Booking. I.e. the column`s value is NULL, when the Label Booking is done for Rotables positioned directly on "Aircraft Level". The column is however different from NULL, when the Label Booking is either done for LRU-Parts located within Higher Assemblies in an Aircraft, or for a "Component Tree Label Booking" (= Assembly in a Shop). Note that this column is about the "Highest Assy". To get info about the "Higher Assy" of a Label Booking, one can still find this data in the "history" DB table.

column1: This table contains data for booked labels, which are only one-way bookings for a particular labelnumber. For example turnaround items, which are received after the removal with a different labelnumber. Or modification items, which are installed / removed without a counterpart. If those marker flags are not present on a label layout, then generally all booked labels without a counterbooking are tracked here.

column5: Description
psn of the rotables that is implied in the label booking. This is null in case of a Repairable Consumables Label Booking
A unique identifier for a one-way booked label.

The type of the one-way booked label. Possible values are: 1 = INSTALLATION_TURNAROUND 2 = INTENTIONAL_INSTALLATION_ONLY 3 = UNINTENDED_INSTALLATION_ONLY 4 = REMOVAL_TURNAROUND 5 = INTENTIONAL_REMOVAL_ONLY 6 = UNINTENDED_REMOVAL_ONLY

If the type of the one-way booked label is "REMOVAL_TURNAROUND" (see column "singlebooking_type" for more info), then this field is filled with the event_perfno_i of a workorder, which at the time of booking the label is written on the generated repair order. This event_perfno_i can then be shown e.g. as reference, when the turnaround rotable is received later.
The link to the table history, where more details for this booking can be found.
The partnumber of the ON- or OFF-Part of this one-way booked label. For component trees, only the highest assy is considered.
The review state of the one-way booked label. The review state can be edited in the program "Bookings Analyzer". Possible values are: 1 = OPEN 2 = CLOSED
Remarks for this one-way booked label. The remarks can be edited in the program "Bookings Analyzer".

- empty if no qulification for this event - `?` if 1..n qualifications, but all without short code - `*` at the beginning, if some qualifications have short code, but others not - `*` at the end, if more than 10 qualifications with short code
Only valid for workorder events.
Priority of wo transfer.
`Y` if feedback is required, otherwise `N`

Each position of the string represents a special characteristic of the event @see AbstractEvent.getSpecialFlagFor(): 0 = ">" 1 = Deprecated: no longer filled! - Pickslip status  2 = HIL (wo_header) 3 = MEL (wo_header_more & wo_header_crx) 4 = ORIGIN (W=wo/R=rotable/C=check/D=document) 5 = REPETITIVE (O=one time/R=repetitive) 6 = WORKORDER PRINTED (PRINTED_BY) (Y=yes/N=no) 7 = W/O issued for removed rotable (Y=yes/N=no) / rotable link OK 8 = W/O for an event (R/C/D) still open (O=open/C=closed) 9 = W/O cannibalized (Y/-) 10 = AOG-Risk (Y/" ") 11 = Taskcard-W/O ? (T/" ") 12 = Within tolerance ("Y"/"N") 13 = Tree-Rotable ? (Y/"-") 14 = Hangar_Required (Y/"-") 15 = Exists check package (Y/-)      16 = Component on open internal or external order (order type R,W,X,C) 17 = Has the event links `Y`,`N` 18 = Has the event remarks `Y`,`N` 19 = Interpolarized toGo value `Y`,`N` 20 = Mandatory event `Y`, `N` 21 = WO approval state (short code from APPROVAL_STATE) 22 = Deprecated: no longer filled! - Taskcard Man Hours for panel available (only valid for single running taskcards). 23 = In case the event was extended `Y` else `N` 24 = Document Event Sate `N`=removal not required, `B`=removal req. without order state ,`U`=removal req. with order state unknown (od_order_doc.performed=U)(documents only) 25 = Entry in wo_stages exists then `Y`, else `N` ONLY FOR WO 26 = Failure case for workorder exists then `Y` else `N` ONLY FOR WO 27 = Repeated item for workorder exists then `Y` else `N` ONLY FOR WO 28 = In case an entry in wo_reference exist `Y`, else `N` ONLY FOR WO 29 = In case an entry in msc_task_req_extension exists `Y` else `N` ONLY FOR SINGLE RUNNING TC 30 = Event classification `L`(Line maintenance), `H`(Heavy maintenance), `` unspecified valid for all events except the workorders. 31 = Marker if for the workorder/SRT a techquery has been raised and the status of this query `-`:no query. `C`: closed, `O` open, `I`: Interrupted 32 = Marker whether the workorder is for a component or an aircraft 33 = Run Required ? (Y/"-") 34 = Skill-Level as it may be defined on the wo shops (feature for GOL)  (0 - 9) 35 = Is the workorder ready for being closed? (Y/"-") (required for the ACJC process) 36 = The type of the workorder (wo_header.type) 59 = "<" (end marker of the special flags)

This is for the MEL category. Letter designators for the different repair intervals: blank space: A: No standard interval defined. B: Items in this category shall be rectified in 3 consecutive calendar days, excluding the day of discovery. C: Items in this category shall be rectified in 10 consecutive calendar days, excluding the day of discovery. D: Items in this category shall be rectified in 120 consecutive calendar days, excluding the day of discovery. L: CDL category. F: NEF category. Items in this category inherit from the operator limitation values. N: No category defined.

This is for the SLA category. Has to be less or equal to entries in the category column. Letter designators for the different repair intervals: blank space: A: No standard interval defined. B: Items in this category shall be rectified in 3 consecutive calendar days, excluding the day of discovery. C: Items in this category shall be rectified in 10 consecutive calendar days, excluding the day of discovery. D: Items in this category shall be rectified in 120 consecutive calendar days, excluding the day of discovery.

column1: This table contains all information about AMOS-logins.

Time of the last failed login-try

the salt which is used to calculate the individual password hash
the number of iterations for calculating the password hash
Unique Login-Sign of each user
Hashing algorithm used for one-way encoding of login_hash.
One-Way encoded login of the user.
This column stored the authentication-mode: PASSWORD: Password is stored in AMOS LDAP: Password is checked via LDAP
Alias used to authenticate against external systems
Date of the last password change.
If activated, a separated log-file for that user is created
Date when the user logged in the last time
Version that was actual when the user logged in the last time. If empty, the user had never logged in before.
The amount of performed logins
Date of the last failed login-try
The amount of failed logins in series. If the user logs in correctly, the counter resets to "0" again. This counter is used to automatically deactivate the login after X failed logins in series.
If set, the login is marked as "Group Login". Such logins are not allowed to change password or to change any personalized settings.
Primary key`s first column
The expire-date of the login. After reaching, the user can`t login any more. If set to "0", the login never expires.
If set, the user is allowed to login from outside the company Intranet.
If filled, the login has only dedicated access to certain aircraft. The type is defined in dedicated_op_type

If filled, the login is bound to another AMOS customer-code than defined in parameter 914. Logos, Release-Statements etc. will change according the customer-code. It can be used to host more than one company in one single AMOS-instance.

column1: Contains the header data for extracted data of OEM documents in context of maintenance programs. In S1000D context the <taskDefinition> element is extracted here and contains the necessary information to define a planned maintenance task. Refere to 3.9.5.2.5 in spec. 4.1

column5: Description
The unit of measure to be used: `d` = day `h` = hour Only used in S1000D context.

The duration for performing the actions specified as preliminary requirements. Only used in S1000D context. The task duration must be given in hours or days with maximum one decimal (eg, 12,5 h, 1,5 d). The three time values and unit of measurement must be entered. The total elapsed time for the maintenance task is built up by populating all three attributes startupDuration, procedureDuration and closeupDuration.

The duration for performing the actions specified in the procedure. Only used in S1000D context. The task duration must be given in hours or days with maximum one decimal (eg, 12,5 h, 1,5 d). The three time values and unit of measurement must be entered. The total elapsed time for the maintenance task is built up by populating all three attributes startupDuration, procedureDuration and closeupDuration.

Tthe duration for performing the actions specified in the Requirements after job completion. Used in S1000D context. The task duration must be given in hours or days with maximum one decimal (eg, 12,5 h, 1,5 d). The three time values and unit of measurement must be entered. The total elapsed time for the maintenance task is built up by populating all three attributes startupDuration, procedureDuration and closeupDuration.
Only used in S1000D context. The unique key to load the applicability/effectivity for this item. This value is linked to s1000d_applicability.applic_ident_value.
Only S1000D context: the skill level required of the person who will perform the task. This attribute can have the following values: "sk01" thru "sk99". Refer to Chap 3.9.6.1. in spec. 4.1

Only S1000D context: the classification of the main technical ability required of the person performing the task (eg, Airframe, Electrical, Avionic, Engine). This attribute can have the following values: "st01" thru "st99". Refer to Chap 3.9.6.1. in spec. 4.1
The level of supervision that is appropriate for the task. Refer to chapter 3.9.5.2.5, Para 2.5.4.
Only used in SGML context.
Only used in SGML context. `Y` = true `N` = false
Only used in SGML context.
Only used in SGML context.

Used in SGML context: A unique identifier for the package of data known as Task having seven elements (spec2200): 2 character for ATA chapter 2 characters for ATA section 2 characters for ATA subject 3 characters for function code 3 characters for unique id. For tasks, the number is in the range 801 through 999. 3 characters for configuration identification 3 characters for airline use The first two (2) digits consist of the primary ATA Chapter Number.
Only used in SGML context.
Only used in SGML context.
The unique identifier for the list of tasks. In context of S1000D: 	taskDefinition/taskIdent In context of SGML: 	unique_key
The ATA subject of this task definition. A 2-digit to 4-digit number. In S1000D context this may have the value `XX` if the subject is not further specified.
The ATA section of this task definition. A 2-digit to 4-digit number. In S1000D context this may have the value `XX` if the section is not further specified.
The ATA chapter of this task definition. A 2-digit to 4-digit number.

The link to the OEM document in oem_doc_revision.
Used in S1000D context: The description of a task definition. See taskDefinition/task/taskDescr. Spec. 4.1 chapter 3.9.5.2.5, para 2.4.2.1.1

column1: Contains information required to determine when a task must be performed. For S1000D context, have a look into the spec. 4.1: chapter 3.9.5.2.5, para 2.4.1.1

column5: Description

Link to a threshold definition defining the `from` value of a range.

The link to the limit information in terms of a value before which the inspection must be performed. The value can be given in calendar time or in other terms such as the number of hours a Product has been operating.

<sampling> contains a description of a subset of the total number of Product instances on which the inspection must be performed. The sampling can be given as a percentage, a fraction or as a textual description. This element is omitted if the inspection must be performed on the full set of Products.

In S1000D context, the value of attribute `limitTypeValue (O)`. This attribute is used to indicate the limit classification (it contains one of the following values. If no value is specified, the default value "PE" is implied.  "PO" = perform once  "PE" = perform periodically  "OC" = On condition

column1: This table contains the relationship between two tasks. In the spec 4.1 refer to chapter 3.9.5.2.5, para 2.5.5.

column5: Description
The no_i of the linked OEM document in oem_doc_revision.
Link to the header data of the related task.

In S1000D context: the nature of the association. This attribute can have the following values: - "after" - Perform maintenance requirement after related requirement is started - "before" - Perform maintenance requirement before related requirement - "complied" - Maintenance requirement is complied with by related requirement - "finished" - Cannot finish maintenance requirement until related requirement is finished - "precludes" - Maintenance requirement precludes related requirement - "started" - Cannot finish the maintenance requirement until related requirement is started - "with" - Perform maintenance requirement with related requirement Refer to chapter 3.9.5.2.5, para 2.5.5.
In S1000D context: the task identifier that has an association to the current task (via the attribute taskIdent of the related task)

First column of the primary key

Property to distinguish whether this "Pending Part Definition" has its origins in a "manual request" or rather came automatically into the system. "Manual Request" is for example, when the User creates the "Pending Part Definition" directly in a UI Partnumber Field, or by clicking on the HTML MimeType of an unknown Partnumber, without specifying a concrete "Source Type" like "Part Request" or similar. When this column is "false", then the automatic clean-up job for outdated "Pending Part Definitions" will consider this entry in its list for to-be-checked Part Definitions (still applicable, i.e. Part Request with same unknown Partnumber still exists?).
Contains the XML representation of the "Pending Part Definition" data, as used for the working copy of that Part Definition (i.e. the latest data entered by the responsible Users).

PrimaryKey. Also used as MimeType for PPEvents.

Aircraft-registration the PPEvent occurred on.
Operator of the aircraft stored in ac_reg.
Position of the part in the aircraft.
TAH - total Aircraft Hours
TAC - Total aircraft Cycles
TSN - Time Since New
CSN - Cycles Since New
TBI/TSI
CBI/CSI
TSO - Time Since Overhaul
CSO - Cycles Since Overhaul
TSR - Time Since Repair
CSR - Cycles Since Repair
Station.

Type the PPEvent is of. Should be one of the following:  0	=	 "OTHER" 4	=	 "INFLIGHT SHUTDOWN" 9	=	 "BIRD STRIKE" 10	=	 "ABORTED TAKEOFF" 17	=	 "ONE ENG OUT LANDING" 18	=	 "AIR START FAIL" 19	=	 "GROUND START FAIL" 24	=	 "FOD" 27	=	 "AUTO SHUTDOWN" 30	=	 "APU CAUSED IFSD" 31	=	 "TREND SHIFT" 50	=	 "OCCURRENCE"
The event_perfno_i of the workordernumber linked to this PPEvent.

PPEvents references.

Shop costs.
TAT - Turn Around Time
PSN for the part- and serialnumber-field
Flag indication that the Event is closed. true = `Y` false = `N`, NULL
Source the PPEvent was created from. Options are: WO, AET, NULL. 											PPEvents can be created from a Workorder (WO), an "Aircraft Event Tracking"-Event (AET) or by a user (NULL).
The sources AMOS-MimeType. Could be WO for Workorders or AET for "Aircraft Event Tracking"-Events. 											User-created PPEvents do not have a MimeType.
Type of aircraft the PPEVENT occurred on.

Conclusion by the shop.

column1: This database table stores entries which are written by the AMOS application "Part & Software Booking" (PSB).

column5: Description
Primary Key of this database table.
The Labelnumber which is used for the "Part & Software Booking" (PSB).
If given, describes the Partnumber of the Removal Item for the PSB.
If given, describes the Serialnumber of the Removal Item for the PSB.

If given, describes the Batchnumber of the Removal Item for this PSB. Only valid / applicable when the removed Material is of Mat.-Class "Repairable Consumable". Not used when the removed Item is a "Rotable".

If given, contains the quantity of the removed "Repairable Consumable" Item(s) for this PSB. Only valid / applicable when the removed Material is of Mat.-Class "Repairable Consumable". Not used when the removed Item is a "Rotable".

If given, contains the Owner of the removed "Repairable Consumable" Item(s) for this PSB. An Owner needs to be specified during the PSB transaction, because those "Repairable Consumable" Item(s) are created afresh in AMOS (new Material). Only valid / applicable when the removed Material is of Mat.-Class "Repairable Consumable". Not used when the removed Item is a "Rotable".

If given, contains the "Financial Entity" of the removed "Repairable Consumable" Item(s) for this PSB. A "Financial Entity" needs to be specified during the PSB transaction, because those "Repairable Consumable" Item(s) are created afresh in AMOS (new Material). Only valid / applicable when the removed Material is of Mat.-Class "Repairable Consumable". Not used when the removed Item is a "Rotable".
If set to "Y(ES)", the Removal Item of the PSB is marked as "Undetermined" (not fully identified yet).
If the Removal Item of the PSB is marked as "Undetermined", then this database field can contain some description text for this occurrence.
ID of the Maintenance Event (e.g. Workorder) for which the "Part & Software Booking" was performed.
ID of the Financial Project to which the "Part & Software Booking" is related.
Aircraft Registration for which the "Part & Software Booking" was performed.
Link to the Aircraft Position ("Uncontrolled / Controlled Position") at which the Part Item Removal / Installation occurred.
Station at which the "Part & Software Booking" was performed.
Date at which the "Part & Software Booking" was physically performed.
"Total Aircraft Minutes" at which the "Part & Software Booking" was performed.
"Total Aircraft Cycles" at which the "Part & Software Booking" was performed.
User sign of the person who physically performed the work concerning the Part Item Removal / Installation.

Defines the type when the PSB transaction is a "one-way booked label". Possible values are: 1 = INSTALLATION_TURNAROUND 2 = INTENTIONAL_INSTALLATION_ONLY 3 = UNINTENDED_INSTALLATION_ONLY 4 = REMOVAL_TURNAROUND 5 = INTENTIONAL_REMOVAL_ONLY 6 = UNINTENDED_REMOVAL_ONLY
When a Removal is booked during a PSB transaction, then this database field contains the "locationno_i" ID of the "U/S (Unserviceable) Location" at which the removed Item is located after Removal.
In case of a Removal for the PSB, this database field can contain some "Removal Reason" text (might later be displayed in the generated Repair Order for example).
In case of a Removal for the PSB, describes if the Removal is "Scheduled (SD)" or "Unscheduled (US)".
Is set to "Y(ES)" when the Removal Item of the PSB is marked as "Troubleshooting".

column1: This table contains links to transactions that ultimately make up for a Swap. In a Swap, there`s a Removal and Installation of Rotable 1, and as well a Removal and Installation of Rotable 2. The Swap of these Rotables can occur within one Aircraft, or there can be 2 Aircraft involved as well. There are 2 Labels involved to consolidate this "Swap" transaction.

column5: Description
Primary key for a "Swap" transaction.
Contains Labelno 1 which takes part in the "Swap" transaction.

Contains link to "history" table (historyno_i). The link will specify the "Removal Label Booking" portion of Labelno 1 (Rotable 1 gets removed, "YA" entry in "Parts Tracking"). Labelno 1 itself is part of the whole "Swap" transaction.

Contains link to "history" table (historyno_i). The link will specify the "Installation Label Booking" portion of Labelno 1 (Rotable 2 gets installed, "YE" entry in "Parts Tracking"). Labelno 1 itself is part of the whole "Swap" transaction.
Contains Labelno 2 which takes part in the "Swap" transaction.

Contains link to "history" table (historyno_i). The link will specify the "Removal Label Booking" portion of Labelno 2 (Rotable 2 gets removed, "YA" entry in "Parts Tracking"). Labelno 2 itself is part of the whole "Swap" transaction.

Contains link to "history" table (historyno_i). The link will specify the "Installation Label Booking" portion of Labelno 2 (Rotable 1 gets installed, "YE" entry in "Parts Tracking"). Labelno 2 itself is part of the whole "Swap" transaction.

Contains link to "history" table (historyno_i). The link will specify the "Release to Service" transaction of Rotable 1 ("B1" entry in "Parts Tracking", stored in database table "history") which occurs after the preceding Removal of Rotable 1. Note that this "Release to Service" entry for the "Swap" may be "NULL" as it gets only written if the "Swap" was done between 2 Aircraft. A "Swap" of Rotables within one Aircraft will not trigger a writing of such a "B1 Release to Service" entry.

Contains link to "history" table (historyno_i). The link will specify the "Release to Service" transaction of Rotable 2 ("B1" entry in "Parts Tracking", stored in database table "history") which occurs after the preceding Removal of Rotable 2. Note that this "Release to Service" entry for the "Swap" may be "NULL" as it gets only written if the "Swap" was done between 2 Aircraft. A "Swap" of Rotables within one Aircraft will not trigger a writing of such a "B1 Release to Service" entry.

column1: S1000D CIR data: Access point repository

column5: Description

Extracted from the S1000D specification 4.1 (chapter 3.9.5.2.1.1 - 2.4.1): - changeType (O), the type of the change:  "add", the element is added  "modify", the element has been changed Note: Elements that have the attribute changeType set to the value "modify" may contain elements that have this attribute set to the value "add", "modify" or "delete". These values on the child elements must be taken into account.  "delete", the element has been deleted Note The attribute changeType can apply to any element and not especially to the element where the change occurs. Depending on the type of the change, propagation rules defining the change marking inheritance from the upper element to the lower may differ: - Elements marked with the value modify are allowed to contain elements marked with values add, modify or delete - Elements marked with the value delete: There is no need to set the change attributes on the elements children because this is implied. Any change markings on child elements are ignored by the presentation system. - Elements marked with value add: There is no need to set the change attributes on the elements children because this is implied. Any change markings on child elements are ignored by the presentation system. Note: If this attribute is not used, and the attribute changeMark is used, the change is assumed to be an addition.

Extracted from the S1000D specification 4.1 (chapter 3.9.5.2.1.1 - 2.4.1): - changeMark (O), indicates whether the display of a change bar, mark or other visual indication next to the entire content of an element being added, deleted or modified is intended. The values for this attribute are:  "1", the display of a change bar, mark or other visual indication is intended  "0", the display of a change bar, mark or other visual indication is not intended Note: If the attribute changeMark is not used, then there is no display of a change bar, mark or other visual indication intended. Note: `-2` as value means that this row was inserted before the changeMark support was added to AMOS. `-1` as value means that there is no changeMark flag set in the document for this element.

The element techName content must reflect the name of the hardware or function. That is, it must reflect the system, subsystem or sub-subsystem concerned.

The element infoName is linked to the information code using the attribute infoCode. Normally the information name is the short description of the information code. For example, information code 520 will have information name "Remove procedure". Projects can decide to modify (or extend) the information name to one that is more suitable, provided the sense of the information code is maintained. An example of where this could be used would be the information code 251 is "Clean procedures". A project can have a data module that tells the reader how to clean with water (this could be 251A) another data module could tell the reader how to clean with air (this could be 251B). In both cases, the information name can be extended from "Clean procedures" to "Clean procedures (clean with water)" and "Clean procedures (clean with air)".
URN to the data module code reference.

Airbus has set up a new policy for the sourcing of specific equipment (seats, IFE) with contracted suppliers. This sourcing model is called ACS for Airbus Contracted Suppliers. This modification is introduced in order to inform the customer that a part is covered by the ACS policy. Indeed it might induce specific management regarding the sourcing in order to take fully advantage of the ACS policy. In the Part CIR data module context, the ACS parts are flagged using the procurementData/sourcingType attribute: this element is systematically delivered for parts with an ACS contract. Otherwise it is not delivered. The sourcingType/@sourcingTypeValue attribute is systematically delivered and set to stv51 to indicate the part has an ACS contract.
the overlength part number
the limited partno
The <buyerFurnishedEquipFlag> element is used as a flag to indicate that the part is furnished by the customer.
4.0.1 only. Name.

This column gives an abbreviated alternate name of the part corresponding to the element <name>/<descrForPart>. This short form for the name of the part is meant to be presented in the narrative of the data module to make reading easier.
The keyword (<partKeyword> element) containing a the single word name of a part as defined by the project.
Description text for this part.
The CAGE code of the manufacturer of this part.
The actual part number of an item (which is allocated by the design  authority of the equipment).
The reference to the OEM document to which this entry belongs to.

Extracted from the S1000D specification 4.1 (chapter 3.9.5.2.1.1 - 2.4.1): - changeType (O), the type of the change:  "add", the element is added  "modify", the element has been changed Note: Elements that have the attribute changeType set to the value "modify" may contain elements that have this attribute set to the value "add", "modify" or "delete". These values on the child elements must be taken into account.  "delete", the element has been deleted Note The attribute changeType can apply to any element and not especially to the element where the change occurs. Depending on the type of the change, propagation rules defining the change marking inheritance from the upper element to the lower may differ: - Elements marked with the value modify are allowed to contain elements marked with values add, modify or delete - Elements marked with the value delete: There is no need to set the change attributes on the elements children because this is implied. Any change markings on child elements are ignored by the presentation system. - Elements marked with value add: There is no need to set the change attributes on the elements children because this is implied. Any change markings on child elements are ignored by the presentation system. Note: If this attribute is not used, and the attribute changeMark is used, the change is assumed to be an addition.

column1: Defines how the PQS Types are linked together in a tree view.

column5: Description
Primary Key of the table
The no i of the PQS Type used as parent
The no i of the PQS Type used as child

The record number: it is set for each group of associations of the parent PQS Type no i. There can be several ways of getting a parent PQS Type no i, therefore a record number is set for each of these possibility. It allows also to manage priorities among the PQS Type no i

Indicates if the parent PQS Type no i is a limitation of the child PQS Type no i N => No limitation: for most of the cases O => Only limitation: Only the data defined by the parent PQS Type no i are used E => Except limitation: All the data defined by the child PQS Type no i are used except the ones defined by the parent PQS Type no i
Indicates if the parent PQS Type no i is a refresher of the child PQS Type no i N => No : for most of the cases Y => Yes : the parent PQS Type no i is a refresher for the child PQS Type no i

event_perfno_i

0 = ">" 1 = Pickslip status @see amos.server.forecast.workorder.WorkorderForecast.checkPickslipForPart() 2 = HIL (wo_header) 3 = MEL (wo_header_more & wo_header_crx) 4 = ORIGIN (W=wo/R=rotable/C=check/D=document) 5 = REPETITIVE (O=one time/R=repetitive) 6 = WORKORDER PRINTED (PRINTED_BY) (Y=yes/N=no) 7 = W/O issued for removed rotable (Y=yes/N=no) / rotable link OK 8 = W/O for an event (R/C/D/T) still open (Y=open/N=closed) 9 = W/O cannibalized (Y/-) 10 = AOG-Risk (Y/" ") 11 = Taskcard-W/O ? (T/" ") 12 = Within tolerance ("Y"/"N") 13 = Tree-Rotable ? (Y/"-") 14 = Hangar_Required (Y/"-") 15 = Exists check package (Y/-) 16 = Component on open internal or external order (order type R,W,X,C) 17 = Has the event links `Y`,`N` 18 = Has the event remarks `Y`,`N` 19 = Interpolarized toGo value `Y`,`N` 20 = Mandatory event `Y`, `N` 21 = WO approval state (short code from APPROVAL_STATE) 22 = Taskcard Man Hours for panel available (only valid for single running taskcards). 23 = In case the event was extended `Y` else `N` 24 = Document Event Sate `N`=removal not required, `B`=removal req. without order state ,  `U`=removal req. with order state unknown (od_order_doc.performed=U)   (documents only) 25 = Entry in wo_stages exists then `Y`, else `N` ONLY FOR WO 26 = Failure case for workorder exists then `Y` else `N` ONLY FOR WO 27 = Repeated item for workorder exists then `Y` else `N` ONLY FOR WO 28 = In case an entry in wo_reference exist `Y`, else `N` ONLY FOR WO 29 = In case an entry in msc_task_req_extension exists `Y` else `N` ONLY FOR SINGLE RUNNING TC 30 = Event classification `L`(Line maintenance), `H`(Heavy maintenance), `` unspecified valid for all events except the workorders. 31 = Marker if for the workorder/SRT a techquery has been raised and the status of this query `-`:no query. `C`: closed, `O` open, `I`: Interrupted 32 = Marker whether the workorder is for a component or an aircraft 33 = Run Required ? (Y/"-") 34 = Skill-Level as it may be defined on the wo shops (feature for GOL)  (0 - 9) 35 = Is the workorder ready for being closed? (Y/"-") (required for the ACJC process) 36 = The type of the workorder (wo_header.type) 37 = The rotable needs to be removed to perform the requirement ("Y"/"N") only filled for rotables

column5: Description
Prime key of the replacment events.

This column replaces the column `planable` which has been set as deprecated. The new planable_status = 0 is equivalent to the former planable = `Y` Any other planable_status value indicates that the event is not planable. It is equivalent to the former planable = `N`

Effectivity linked to the Maintenance Event. This might differ from the active effectivity linked to the Maintenance Requirement. From 10.90, this is only filled for Documents entries identified with event_type = DOC_EFF
FK to the maintenance event header

Indicates if the future maintenance events of the current pending should be reinitialised and how. Following values are allowed: Y: Future Events should be reinitialised U: Future Events should be initialised for Unlimited Time Requirements E: Only existing Future Events should be reinitialised N: Future Events should not be reinitialised null: Future Events should not be reinitialised This column is introduced from 10.90 onwards.
Link to wo_header table
Type related to each maintenance event. Check: MEC Document: MED Part Requirement: MEP Part Replacment: MER Taskcard: MET
only used for Replacement events -> event_type = MEP  All other Maintenance Events are managed "ONLY" with the effectivity_linkno_i

Is the key of the direct requirement linked to the event. TASKCARD: msc_requirement_tc_link.req_linkno_i CHECH: check_type_int.check_intno_i DOCUMENT: doc_header.docno_i PART REQUIREMENT: part_requirement.part_requirementno_i PART REPLACEMENT: part.partseqno_i

Is the key of the root requirement linked to the event.   TASKARD: msc_req_link_header.req_link_headerno_i (msc_req_link_header is the root of msc_requirement_tc_link) CHECK: check_type.checkno_i (check_type is the root of check_type_int) ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- For the bellow requirement event_key_root = event_key_parent no hierarchy used for events -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- DOCUMENT: doc_header.docno_i PART REQUIREMENT: part_requirement.part_requirementno_i PART REPLACEMENT: part.partseqno_i
Flag for pending status. Value greater than zero: entry is a future event Value less than zero: entry is a historic event Value is equal to zero: entry is the current pending entry

The status of the event.  ON ATTRITION(A), POSTPONED OPEN (B), CLOSED (C), DELETE ASSIGNMENTS (D), EVENT TRIGGERED (E), EXFACTORY (F), TERMACTION OPEN (G), ROTABLE DRIVEN ACCOMPLISHED (H), INFORMATION ONLY (I), REJECTED BY OPERATOR ,(J), ROTABLE DRIVEN NOT ACCOMPLISHED (K), LOGBOOK CONTROLLED (L), TASKCARD CONTROLLED (M), NOT APPLICABLE (N), OPEN (O), PARTLY PERFORMED (P), PARTREQ CONTROLLED (Q), REPETITIVE (R), DOCUMENT IN PREPARATION (S), TERMINATED BY THIRD PARTY (T), CANCELLED (U), PERF BY PEVIOUS OPERATOR (V), SEE PREV DOC STATUS (W), EXTERNALLY CONTROLLED (X), REOPEN (Y), SUPERSEDED (Z), UNKNOWN (!), UNKNOWN EMPTY ( ), NOT ASSIGNED (-), UNKNOWN ACTYPE (?), NOT INSTALLED (/), NOT PERFORMED (0) AC GROUP CHANGED (1), AC DEACTIVATED (2)
The interval usage after the event is performed. This is the min or max value, depending on first_later logic.
If set to "Y" the event will be reported back automatically when the workorder is closed.

column1: This table is used to save the following objects which are different in the characteristics and behaviour: -	Workorders  -	Work Templates since 9.50 -	Event Pendings since 9.70 - 	Jobcards/Customer Requirements since 11.40 - 	Shopcards/Non-Technical Tasks since 19.12 How can you evaluate the difference?  Following the criteria to do so per object: -	A Workorder is identified by: 	o	wo_header.type = `S` OR `M` OR `C` OR `P` 	o	wo_header.event_perfno_i > 0  	o	wo_header.workorderno_display is not null -	A Work Template is identified by: 	o	wo_header.type = `T` 	o	wo_header.event_perfno_i < 0 -	An Event Pending is identified by: 	o	wo_header.type = `PD` 	o	wo_header.event_perfno_i > 0 	o	wo_header.workorderno_display = null -	A Jobcard is identified by: 	o	wo_header.event_type = `JC` 	o	wo_header.type = `PD` 	o	wo_header.event_perfno_i > 0 	o	wo_header.workorderno_display = null -	A Customer Requirement is identified by: 	o	wo_header.event_type  IN(`CT`,  `CD`, `CC`, `CP`) 	o	wo_header.type = `PD` 	o	wo_header.event_perfno_i > 0 	o	wo_header.workorderno_display = null -	A Shopcard is identified by: 	o	wo_header.event_type  = `SH` 	o	wo_header.type = `PD` 	o	wo_header.event_perfno_i > 0 	o	wo_header.workorderno_display = null -	A Non-Technical Task is identified by: 	o	wo_header.type = `NT` 	o	wo_header.event_perfno_i > 0  	o	wo_header.workorderno_display = null 	o	wo_header.ac_registr = `NONTEC`

column5: Description
Measurement Results from MRO

As a production planner I want to see the customer workorder number related to my internal workorder number so that I can easily identify the relationship.   Business Requirements: An MRO must be able to identify the corresponding airline Workorder number against their own internal workorder number. At time of importing the airline workorder number, the MRO system will generate an own internal workorder number and these two must be easily identified as belonging to each other.
In case of a customer requirement it marks the entry if it is an executable event (`Y`) or not. For non customer requirement entries the entry is not set.
